race.name: Prairie Burn 100
race.tagline: Prairie Burn 100. 100 miles of gravel through Grinnell.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Iowa countryside. Moderate elevation with rolling scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Local Iowa event. Rolling terrain with good access, moderate costs, 100-mile distance, and small local field.

biased_opinion.summary: Prairie Burn 100 is a local event in Iowa—rolling terrain with moderate elevation over 100 miles. The Iowa countryside is nice and the distance is challenging, but the small local field and limited organization keep it in Tier 4.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid local Iowa century gravel race. Worth it for Iowa/Midwest riders. Not worth traveling for.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're local to Iowa—yes, it's solid. If you're traveling—skip it.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Iowa races: Gravel Worlds, RAGBRAI.

logistics.food: Grinnell has full dining options. Stock nutrition.

non_negotiables.why: Iowa summer weather is variable with heat possible.

logistics.explanation: Aid stations every 10-25 miles with Central Park serving as the hub for 25 and 50-mile route returns. Official timing ends at 3:30 PM with bailout support until 5:00 PM, though the race director warns riders to 'know how to fix a flat' as pickup support is limited.

length.explanation: One hundred miles is proper century distance that demands respect and preparation. The 3500 feet of elevation gain over that distance creates endurance challenge without being punitive. Multiple options at 25, 50, and 100 miles let riders choose their suffering level, but the full distance delivers real gravel credibility. Longer than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

technicality.explanation: Tim Stahl notes 'Iowa has some of the best gravel roads in the world' with terrain described as 'moderate terrain with rolling short steep hills.' Course uses Poweshiek County's 700+ miles of maintained gravel roads designed for agricultural traffic, not technical challenges. Less technical than The Mid South. As Tim Stahl puts it: "What makes a gravel bike is the geometry. It's pretty forgiving, with low, thick tires, and then gearing so you can climb the hills."

elevation.explanation: Stahl warns 'we think of Iowa as flat, but you leave town, there are some impressive hills.' The 3500 feet comes through 'rolling short steep hills or moderate, sustained climbs' rather than single big efforts—accumulated grinding over prairie rollers. Less climbing than The Mid South. As Tim Stahl puts it: "What makes a gravel bike is the geometry. It's pretty forgiving, with low, thick tires, and then gearing so you can climb the hills."

climate.explanation: Second Saturday in June brings Midwest summer weather gambling, though organizers promise 'the PB100 will occur rain or shine! All bike routes will have hard surface rain re-routes if needed.' Morning 8 AM start attempts to beat afternoon heat and storms. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: Central Iowa prairie elevation creates zero altitude concerns. The 'impressive hills' Stahl mentions are about leg-burning grade and accumulated climbing, not thin air at altitude. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Course explores Poweshiek County's network of agricultural gravel roads through farming landscape. Two 'Burner Challenge Segments' in the first 50 miles add competitive elements, but the adventure comes from internal suffering over Iowa's deceptively rolling terrain rather than dramatic scenery.

prestige.explanation: The 2026 edition promises a 'new and better format' after previous iterations, suggesting the event is rebuilding rather than established. Despite claims of being 'legendary,' the race lacks visible pro participation or widespread gravel community recognition.

race_quality.explanation: Well-planned aid station placement and GPS files for all routes show organizational competence. The $50 prizes for Burner Challenge segments verified via Strava add competitive structure, though the 'new and better format' language suggests previous execution needed improvement.

experience.explanation: Post-race includes beer garden, food trucks, and live music by The Surf Zombies creating festival atmosphere. The explicitly 'not competitive' nature focuses on 'having a good time, making connections' rather than pure racing experience.

community.explanation: The 5K Fun Run estimates 1-100 participants, which tells you everything about field size expectations. When your event resurfaces with a 'better format,' it suggests the old community didn't stick around. As Laura Ferguson '90 puts it: "It's community building, but it's also getting people out together, both in an activity and in supporting commerce."

field_depth.explanation: Burner Challenge segments offer $50 prizes across male, female, and non-binary categories, creating some competitive structure. However, the associated 5K estimates just 1-100 participants, suggesting small field sizes without serious racing depth. Thinner field than Ouray Gravel Grinder. As Official Website puts it: "It is chip-timed with competitive options, but riders and runners can get out of it what they desire."

value.explanation: Post-race activities include beer garden, live music, yoga, and farmer's market creating full day experience. Free gravel bike rentals available at Bikes to You for newcomers, showing commitment to growing the sport beyond just race day revenue.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $75-100. Small Iowa college town keeps lodging and dining affordable. Tim Stahl's equipment advice focuses on 'forgiving' gravel bike geometry rather than expensive gear requirements, and free bike rentals lower the barrier to entry for curious riders. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

unsplash_photos.description: water waves hitting the shore during daytime

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Panaracer GravelKing SK
primary.why: Affordable all-rounder. Light knobs add grip without killing speed.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

videos.title: Prairie Burn 100 Gravel Bike Ride June 11th in Grinnell
videos.description: Tim Ellsworth, Imagine Grinnell Board Chair, stops by (with his bike) to talk about the Prairie Burn 100 Gravel Bicycle Ride fundraiser Saturday June 11, 2022.

videos.title: Introducing the 2023 Prairie Burn 100
videos.description: The annual Prairie Burn 100 gravel bike ride fundraiser featuring 25, 50 and 100 mile loops around Grinnell, Iowa will take place again on Saturday, June 10, 2023. NEW this year is an added 5K Fun Run. Register today and make sure you stay in the loop by signing up for our emails or follow us on Facebook and Instagram! https://www.prairieburn100.com/

videos.title: Prairie Burn 100 Gravel Bike Ride Fundraiser
videos.description:
The Prairie Burn 100 is about staying active and enjoying the great outdoors. With routes spanning 25, 50 and 100 miles, you don’t have to be a pro gravel cyclist to participate. The event also helps to fund programs of Imagine Grinnell, a non-profit organization supporting a healthy and sustainable Grinnell community. Sign up for the annual Prairie Burn 100 gravel bike ride fundraiser, starting at 7am on June 11, 2022 in Grinnell, Iowa and bring the whole family for activities taking place in Central Park throughout the day. Activities include:

Yoga in the Park
Family bike ride
Youth art activity

More info - https://www.prairieburn100.com/
Learn more - https://www.bikereg.com/prairie-burn
videos.curation_reason: Official race video with highest view count providing overview of the event and its charitable mission.

videos.title: Introducing the 2026 Prairie Burn 100 | June 6, 2026
videos.description: On June 6, 2026, get ready to join our annual gravel bike ride – with routes spanning 25, 50 and 100 kilometers – and a 5K/3K Fun Run centered in Grinnell, Iowa. Mark your calendars and be sure to sign up for emails for updates on event specifics like food vendors, music and family-friendly activities!

quotes.text: You can ride on gravel two three hours sometimes and see one car so you can go for that aspect so you don't have the target on your bike like you do on the road. We think they're much safer than riding on the road and you there's just so many more of them than riding on the trails.

There's about 79,000 miles of gravel in Iowa and so we can pick routes north south east west depending on the wind so these are gravel rides 100 almost 100 percent. We get out of town right on gravel.
